entry.title: Calculating molarity, weight concentration from absorbance value for plasmonic nanoparticles in solution
entry.summary:
It is common to measure the peak absorbance of the plasmonic nanoparticles in solution and then get the following:

  1. Molarity (moles/liter)
  2. Number of particles per ml
  3. Weight concentration (ug/ml)

I wrote a small python function to extract these parameters.  The following inputs are needed for the function

  1. d_nm …
entry.content:
It is common to measure the peak absorbance of the plasmonic nanoparticles in solution and then get the following:

  1. Molarity (moles/liter)
  2. Number of particles per ml
  3. Weight concentration (ug/ml)

I wrote a small python function to extract these parameters.  The following inputs are needed for the function

  1. d_nm :   diameter of the particle in nanoparticle
  2. od :  peak OD measured from the absorbance plot
  3. path_length_cm :  cuvette length in centimeter
  4. density_g_per_cm3 :  for gold it is 19.28, for silver it is 10.49
  5. molar_Extinction_perM_percm :  Molar extinction coefficient extracted from here.
  6. This can extracted from measuring absorbance at different concentrations and then fitting a linear line. the slope will be molar extinction coefficient

Here is the code.

entry.title: Fitting Complex Metal Dielectric Functions with Differential Evolution Method
entry.summary: I use differential evolution method to fit the dielectric functions of metals using Differential Evolution method.

       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;

.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */

}

div.output_scroll {

div.output_text {

.highlight .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The real and imaginary part of dielectric permittivity of the metals is important to simulate the optical properties of metal films and nanoparticles. Permittivity data is obtained experimentally by ellipsometry and is fitted with analytical models. The most common model for fitting experimental data is with Drude-Lorentz model shown below.</p>
$$\epsilon(\omega)=1-\frac{f_1\omega_p^2}{(\omega^2+i\Gamma_1\omega)}+\sum_{j=2}^{n}\frac{f_j\omega_p^2}{(\omega_{o,j}^2-\omega^2-i\Gamma_j\omega)}$$<p>The first term is the Drude part. It represents the response of electron in the Fermi sea/conduction band when it sees external oscillating electric field (these transitions are called as intraband transitions). The Drude term has the plasma frequency ($\omega_p$, oscillator strengh ($f_1$) and damping term ($\Gamma_1$). The rest of the terms represent the Lorentz oscillators with specific resonance frequencies ($\omega_{o,j}$), oscillator strengths ($f_{j}$) and damping terms($\Gamma_j$) associated with them. They represent electron excitation from one band to another following an external oscillating electric field at certain resonance frequencies (these transitions are called as interband transitions).</p>
<p>Just out of curiosity, I wanted to do this fitting by myself for a long time now. So I attempted to fit the data with he commonly used fitting method, the least squares method, which involves minimization of the square of the error between the model and experimental data, while changing the parameters.  However I was not getting good fitting results even with several attempts, this may be due to the following problems with this method:</p>
<ul>
<li>The fits were very sensitive to the initial guess values of the parameters (oscillator strengths, damping terms, etc). </li>
<li>The method is a local minimization technique. What that means is that the least square algorithm (Levenberg - Marquardt ) is changing the parameters in parameter space and searching for the minimum of sum of squares of difference between model and data. While doing this it can get trapped in a local minimum and report the parameters at that point as if it was as global minimum.
For more information on the problems of least-square method. See the last section of the article <a href ="http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/pmd/section1/pmd141.htm">here</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>To avoid these problems, researchers use global optimization techniques. See, <a href ="https://www.osapublishing.org/ao/abstract.cfm?uri=ao-37-22-5271 "> Rakic et al.</a>  and  <a href =" http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1464-4258/2/5/318/meta"> Djurisic et al.</a>. Rakic et al. used simulated annealing method , whic is a global optimization method and does a great job fitting experimental data. I wanted to use <a href="http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.anneal.html">Scipy's simulated annealing method</a> to fit the dielectric functions, but found that simulated annealing algorithm is deprecated in scipy 0.14 and they suggest using basin-hopping or differential evolution (DE) algorithms instead.</p>
<p>I gave DE method a try because I didnot see any research article using DE algorithm for fitting dielectric data. If any of the readers find an article that uses DE to fit complex dielectric function, please point me to the article.  DE algorithm is a stochastic method that does not involve finding a gradient but rather involves mutation and recombination of random population of solutions. I dont completely understand the guts of the algorithm, but you can find more information <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution">here</a>.</p>
<p>Below is my code of how I do the fitting of gold dielectric function with python and lmfit module. lmfit is a python module that provides a better and convinient fitting and optimization interface for Scipy optimize/minimze methods. The default minimization technique for lmfit is least square (Levenberg-marquardt) methood, so it needs to be changed to differential evolution.</p>
<p>You can download my ipython notebook <a href="https://gist.github.com/plasmon360/ccf97d5d600ca4a3197ffa0e3d6cbe0b"> here</a></p>
<p>You can use this method for fitting other dielectric data, but have to tweak the bounds a little bit. If you use my implementation for your fitting your experimental data, please let me know or even better cite it as:</p>
<p>Juluri B.K. "Fitting Complex Metal Dielectric Functions with Differential Evolution Method". <a href="http://juluribk.com/?p=1597">http://juluribk.com/?p=1597</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In the following code, I get the gold's experimental dielectric data from <a href="http://refractiveindex.info/">Refractiveindex.info</a>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">urllib2</span> <span class="c1"># To make a request and gather data,</span>

<span class="c1"># Query the website</span>

<span class="n">response</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">urllib2</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">urlopen</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'http://refractiveindex.info/database/main/Au/Babar.yml'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Alternative Experimental data sources</span>
<span class="c1"># response = urllib2.urlopen('http://refractiveindex.info/database/main/Au/McPeak.yml')</span>
<span class="c1"># response = urllib2.urlopen('http://refractiveindex.info/database/main/Au/Lemarchand-3.96nm.yml')</span>

<span class="c1"># Read the response. Response is in YAML format. Will use PyYAML parser,</span>
<span class="n">yaml_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">response</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">yaml</span>
<span class="n">data</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="n">yaml</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">load</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yaml_data</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Lets see what is inside the data,</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="s2">"Keys in the data:"</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">()</span> 

<span class="c1"># Lets print the reference for this data,</span>
<span class="nb">print</span> <span class="s2">"Reference : "</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'REFERENCES'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'COMMENTS'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">():</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span> <span class="s2">"Comments : "</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'COMMENTS'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="c1"># Data seems to be stored in 'DATA', if needed uncomment the following line</span>
<span class="c1">#print(data['DATA'])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Keys in the data: ['REFERENCES', 'DATA']
Reference :  S. Babar and J. H. Weaver. Optical constants of Cu, Ag, and Au revisited, <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/AO.54.000477"><i>Appl. Opt.</i> <b>54</b>, 477-481 (2015)</a>
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Data string contains real and imaginary part of the refractive index (not dielectric permitivitty). I clean up the real and imaginary part of the refractive data and convert them to dielectric permittivities</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Some clean up needed. The required data string holding wavelength, n and k, is in the form of dictionary item </span>
<span class="c1"># with key 'data', which is inside a list\n",</span>

<span class="n">cleaned_nk</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'DATA'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'data'</span><span class="p">]</span> 

<span class="c1"># Use StringIO to convert String buffer as a file like class\n",</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">StringIO</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">StringIO</span>

<span class="c1"># Read the data into as numpy vectors\n",</span>
<span class="n">wave_micron</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">k</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">genfromtxt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">StringIO</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cleaned_nk</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">unpack</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">wave_exp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">wave_micron</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">1000</span> <span class="c1"># Convert wavelength from microns to nm</span>
<span class="n">eps_exp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span><span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span>  <span class="c1"># Convert n,k into dielectric function</span>

<span class="c1"># Lets convert wavelengh in nm to eV and assign it to 'w' </span>
<span class="n">h</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">4.135667516E-15</span> <span class="c1"># plancks's constant in eV-sec</span>
<span class="n">c</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">299792458E9</span> <span class="c1"># speed of light in vacuum in nm/sec</span>
<span class="n">w_exp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">h</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">wave_exp</span><span class="p">;</span>  <span class="c1"># Convert wavleength in nm to eV</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I define a function that will plot experimental dielectric data. It will also plot fitted models if the data is provided.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_exp</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">w_for_fit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_fit_result</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">'''</span>
<span class="sd">    This functions plots the experimental dielectric function as function of wavelength.</span>
<span class="sd">    If fitted model data is available it will also plot it</span>
<span class="sd">    '''</span>

    <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
    <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
    <span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.ticker</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">ScalarFormatter</span>
    <span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">rcParams</span>
    
    <span class="n">rcParams</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">update</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'font.size'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">18</span><span class="p">})</span> <span class="c1"># Increase the font size</span>
    <span class="n">rcParams</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'mathtext.default'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'regular'</span> <span class="c1"># make the mathtext the same size of normal text for better readbility</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Plot the real part of the dielectric function</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eps_exp</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">real</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">marker</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'o'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">facecolor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'none'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">edgecolor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'g'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Energy (eV)'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="sa">r</span><span class="s1">'|$\epsilon^\prime$|'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        

    <span class="c1"># Plot the imaginary part of the dielectric function</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">eps_exp</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">imag</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">marker</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'o'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">facecolor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'none'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">edgecolor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'g'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="sa">r</span><span class="s1">'$\epsilon ^ {\prime \prime}$'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Energy (eV)'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># If the fit data is available we will plot it with the actual plots</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_for_fit</span> <span class="ow">is</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="kc">None</span> <span class="ow">and</span> <span class="n">eps_fit_result</span> <span class="ow">is</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_for_fit</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eps_fit_result</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">real</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="s1">'-r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_for_fit</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_fit_result</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">imag</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'-r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        
    
    <span class="c1"># Set the grid, log and axis formatter</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">grid</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'on'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xscale</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_yscale</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xlim</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="nb">min</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">),</span><span class="nb">max</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">)])</span>
        <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x_yaxis</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xaxis</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">yaxis</span><span class="p">]:</span>
            <span class="n">x_yaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_major_formatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ScalarFormatter</span><span class="p">())</span>
            
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tight_layout</span><span class="p">()</span>
 
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Lets plot the experimental data to see the data. Data seems to be from 0.1ev to 10eV. There seems to be three transitions (are all of them interband?) above 1eV</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">plot_fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_exp</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Lets define a Drude-Lorentz model. This will be the model we will try to fit the experimental data with. The model has one Drude term and five Lorentz oscillators</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">drude_lorentz_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">'''</span>
<span class="sd">    This is functional representation of drude lorentz model with the first term being Drude</span>
<span class="sd">    and the rest terms being lorentz oscillators</span>
<span class="sd">    '''</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Get the plasma frequency</span>
    <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega_p'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
   
    
    <span class="c1"># Get the Drude parms</span>
    <span class="n">f0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f0'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma0</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma0'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>

    <span class="c1"># Get the first Lorentz term parameters,</span>
    <span class="n">f1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">omega1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Get the second Lorentz term parameters</span>
    <span class="n">f2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">omega2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega2'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Get the third Lorentz term parameters</span>
    <span class="n">f3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">omega3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega3'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>

    <span class="c1"># Get the fourth Lorentz term parameters</span>
    <span class="n">f4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">omega4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega4'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Get the fifth Lorentz term parameters</span>
    <span class="n">f5</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'f5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">gamma5</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Gamma5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>
    <span class="n">omega5</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Omega5'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value</span>

    <span class="c1"># Drude component</span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_D</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f0</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">gamma0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">))</span>

    <span class="c1"># Lorentz first oscillator</span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_L1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f1</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">omega1</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">gamma1</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="c1"># Lorentz SEcond oscillator </span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_L2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">omega2</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">gamma2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="c1"># Lorentz Third oscillator </span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_L3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f3</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">omega3</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">gamma3</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Lorentz Fourth oscillator </span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_L4</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f4</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">omega4</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">gamma4</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># Lorentz Fifth oscillator </span>
    <span class="n">epsilon_L5</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f5</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">omega_p</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">omega5</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">w</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="n">j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">gamma5</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>

    <span class="c1"># Sum all the terms</span>
    <span class="n">epsilon</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">epsilon_D</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">epsilon_L1</span> <span class="o">+</span><span class="n">epsilon_L2</span> <span class="o">+</span>  <span class="n">epsilon_L3</span> <span class="o">+</span>  <span class="n">epsilon_L4</span> <span class="o">+</span>  <span class="n">epsilon_L5</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">epsilon</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Lets define a callable function which returns a residual. This function will be used by our minimization algorithm. It is important to note how the residual is calculated as it is little bit different than normal fitting examples shown in lmfit, because we are minimizing complex data.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">complex_residuals</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">model</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">w</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">exp_data</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="sd">'''</span>
<span class="sd">    This is the residual function that we will try to minimize.</span>
<span class="sd">    It takes the params dict that has the parameters that need to be found. </span>
<span class="sd">   '''</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'Drude'</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="c1"># Our Drude model</span>
        <span class="n">epsilon</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">drude_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">elif</span> <span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'Drude-Lorentz'</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="c1"># Our Drude model</span>
        <span class="n">epsilon</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">drude_lorentz_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">w</span><span class="p">)</span>
        
    <span class="c1"># Lets calculate our complex residual as the way it is done in page 5264</span>
    <span class="c1"># Rakic, a D.,et al (1998). Optical properties of metallic films for vertical-cavity optoelectronic devices. Applied Optics, 37(22), 5271–83.</span>
    <span class="n">residual</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">abs</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">epsilon</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">real</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">exp_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">real</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">exp_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">real</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">abs</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">epsilon</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">imag</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">exp_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">imag</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">exp_data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">imag</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span>
    
    <span class="c1"># if the residual is being used for least square optimizaiton we should have used</span>
    <span class="c1"># residual = (abs((epsilon.real - exp_data.real)/exp_data.real) + abs((epsilon.imag - exp_data.imag)/exp_data.imag))</span>
    <span class="c1"># least square method does the square of the residual in its algorithm. see http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.leastsq.html</span>

    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">residual</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is where differential evolution will be used to make a fit to the data. Differential evolution algorithm requires bounds for each parameter. I gave resonable bounds based on looking at the experimental data and hope to see what the algorithm does. It seem to do a resonable job and much better job than least squares method. <strong>The fitting results will vary a little bit each time we run this cell. So run the cell couple of times to see if things change for better.</strong></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Note that lmfit should be Version > 0.9.0. We will check this</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">lmfit</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">distutils.version</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">StrictVersion</span>
<span class="k">assert</span> <span class="n">StrictVersion</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lmfit</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">__version__</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="n">StrictVersion</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"0.9.0"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">lmfit</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">minimize</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">Parameters</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">printfuncs</span>

<span class="c1"># Choose the model we want to fit it with </span>
<span class="n">model</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Drude-Lorentz'</span>

<span class="n">params</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Parameters</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega_p'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">8.5</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_p has a value in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Drude Term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f0'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma0'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.03</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Lorentz first Oscillator term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f1'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma1'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span> <span class="p">,</span>  <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega1'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">5</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">5</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_o is oscillator central frequency term  and has units in eV. we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Lorentz Second Oscillator term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f2'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma2'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega2'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">2.5</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">3.5</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_o is oscillator central frequency term  and has units in eV. we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Lorentz Third Oscillator term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f3'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma3'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.01</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega3'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">4</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">3.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">4.5</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_o is oscillator central frequency term  and has units in eV. we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Lorentz Fourth Oscillator term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f4'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma4'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.01</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega4'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">5</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">4.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">5.5</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_o is oscillator central frequency term  and has units in eV. we will add a starting guess here</span>

<span class="c1"># Lorentz Fifth Oscillator term</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'f5'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1E-10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># f  has no units,  we will add a starting guess here </span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gamma5'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.01</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Gamma is damping term and has units in eV, we will add a starting guess here</span>
<span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Omega5'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">value</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">6</span> <span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">5.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">max</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">6.5</span> <span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1"># Omega_o is oscillator central frequency term  and has units in eV. we will add a starting guess here</span>



<span class="c1"># Lets fit to all the data.</span>
<span class="n">w_for_fit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">w_exp</span>
<span class="n">eps_for_fit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">eps_exp</span>

<span class="c1"># if we were to fit only a part of the data such as fit only below 2 ev</span>
<span class="c1">#w_for_fit = w_exp[w_exp<2]</span>
<span class="c1">#eps_for_fit = eps_exp[w_exp<2]</span>


<span class="c1"># Call the minimize function with required parameters and use differential evolution as a method </span>
<span class="n">minimizer_results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">minimize</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">complex_residuals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">args</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">model</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">w_for_fit</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">eps_for_fit</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'differential_evolution'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">strategy</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'best1bin'</span><span class="p">,</span>
                             <span class="n">popsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">tol</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mutation</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">recombination</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.9</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">seed</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">callback</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">disp</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">polish</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">init</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'latinhypercube'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># If we were to fit ith with least squares methods</span>
<span class="c1"># minimizer_results = minimize(complex_residuals, params, args=(model, w_for_fit, eps_for_fit), method = 'leastsq')</span>
                             
<span class="c1">#lets see whether the fit exited successfully?</span>
<span class="nb">print</span> <span class="s2">"Print exited successfully? :  "</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">minimizer_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">success</span>

<span class="c1">#lets see the termination status</span>
<span class="nb">print</span> <span class="s2">"Termination Status: "</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">minimizer_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">message</span>

<span class="c1"># lets print the fit report. We dont need lengthy Correlation table</span>
<span class="n">printfuncs</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">report_fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">minimizer_results</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">show_correl</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Caluclate the epsilon based on the fit results</span>
<span class="n">eps_fit_result</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">drude_lorentz_model</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">minimizer_results</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">w_for_fit</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="c1"># Lets plot the fit data</span>
<span class="n">plot_fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">w_exp</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_exp</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">w_for_fit</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">eps_fit_result</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>
